column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: While I agree with the future of AI being able to diagnose health issues early on to be able to go on preventative treatment but I'd say its extreme to let AI handling the life support decisions pertaining to terminal patients and all...

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: I wouldn't mind such a future, but I would like to have the option to chose between AI systems and traditional human care. While AI can be accurate, different people may prefer different approaches and I believe they should have access to that. I'm in support of using AI to create a society less burdened by end-of-life suffering, but I would also like people to have access to traditional care options if they so choose.

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: I like it to a certain extent. I feel like pattern-finding is indeed one of the things AI is best at, so it's a good idea to use it in that capacity. However, human connection is important for health; it's part of wellness and healthcare. Human connection isn't replaceable. I think AI is great for disease detection. For emotional support for those who are lonely, it's fine and should exist, but it's not ideal.

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3:
The ability of AI to detect mental health concerns and help intervene in suicide cases would be very useful. 
On the other hand, I think terminal patients should be treated by real humans and not spend their remaining time here on earth with a souless robot.

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: I think sick people need a lot of emotional support from nurses and  doctors rather than autonomous recommendations.

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: This future offers benefits like reduced suicide attempts (60%) and less burnout for hospice staff (70%), but raises ethical concerns. AI assisting end-of-life care is valuable, but its autonomous decisions on pain management and life support create discomfort (35%). While AI should support and inform, final decisions must remain with humans to ensure dignity and personal choice.

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: I want this kind of future. In the last stage of life, caregivers need to spend a lot of physical and emotional energy. AI helps them reduce stress and burnout, which is very positive. People may not think completely rationally on major issues such as the end of life. The participation of AI can help people make more rational decisions. Moreover, in this scenario, AI is not the one who makes the choice, but only makes suggestions, so humans still have the initiative.

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: 我認為未來透過AI在生命最後階段提供幫助是有意義的，特別是在識別心理健康問題和提供情感支持方面。AI能夠準確識別自殺風險並提供干預，能大大減少悲劇發生。同時，AI也能為末期患者提供更個性化的護理，減輕家庭和護理人員的壓力。然而，關於AI在死亡決策中的角色，我認為還是需要謹慎，因為這是涉及深刻情感和倫理的問題。

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: I hope to see such a future. The application of AI in hospice care can greatly improve the efficiency of early identification and intervention of mental health problems, reduce suicide rates, provide continuous emotional support to patients, and reduce the emotional pressure of medical staff. However, AI's recommendations on pain management and the timing of life support may conflict with family members, which requires in-depth discussion and regulation at the ethical and legal levels. Overall, the intervention of AI can significantly improve the quality of hospice care, but a balance needs to be found between technology and humanistic care.

column2: Would you want this future or not? Please explain why.
column3: I think I would, but with the caveat it is under qualified human supervision - to be clear, a medical professional. I question the emotional support aspect of this, but the practical planning I think is a great idea - family and friends can be too emotional understandably, to provide guidance in this area. If machine learning can be so advanced as to help intervene in suicide cases arising from mental health issues, I support that too.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: I don't agree. Although consent is necessary, permitting AI agents to reply to messages on the user's behalf might result in misunderstandings, absence of personal touch, and misuse of information. Users would lose control over their personal interactions, and the risk of unintended responses or privacy breaches could be high.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: In this sense, unless they are answers to predetermined questions answered by the user, a human should answer.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: Because while an AI agent can facilitate communication when the user consents, there must be monitoring and control options to ensure privacy, accuracy of context, and to avoid misunderstandings.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: If the user consented to this, why not. Could turn very messy if AI is on the both ends of the conversation though.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: I agree, but with limitations. AI agents can enhance communication by responding efficiently, saving time, and maintaining consistency. However, users should have control over which messages AI can handle and be able to review or override responses when needed. Transparency is key, so recipients should be aware when interacting with AI, especially in sensitive or personal conversations.

column3: I don’t have a preference for either they both have large weaknesses that I find unappealing. Why should lay people have input in making something like vaccines? And why is regulation and oversight considered bad?

column2: Would you prefer Scenario 1 or 2? Please explain what makes one of these scenarios better to you than the other.
column3: 2. Decisions about AI should be made by users

column2: Would you prefer Scenario 1 or 2? Please explain what makes one of these scenarios better to you than the other.
column3: None. A company having 50% of AI models is already problematic enough, as it will inevitably steer its decisions in its favor.

column2: Would you prefer Scenario 1 or 2? Please explain what makes one of these scenarios better to you than the other.
column3: A mix. Scenario 2 is what I would prefer but again this input would be use to the ai so if we're just taking anyone, they could potentially gave a misleading input. So regulations are needed. If not then probably just stick to the usual like scenario 1

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: Some people waste a lot of time deicidng stocks and shares. It is their free will if they want to risk losing money. I presume there will be guidelines as to how much money AI can buy or sell.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: It's the user's money, he should have a say, but if he trusts the AI accepts the risk, fine too. People trust brokers to make decisions for them at times without consulting them too.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: I don't think this gonna work, some users need specific needs of their own so AI cant give the things to needs of people

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: This decision is up to people because AI agents can be programmed to lose and the data does not always represent market sentiment, which can change depending on some news.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: the user must be informed before implementing the AI buying and selling strategy

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: AI is the tool and can make recommendations, but it should not be able to unilaterally make a decision for the user unless explicitly told otherwise.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: This is a type of question that should be answered by humans, but AI can help with decision making.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: AI agents need to take permission from users before they take any decisions as it involves financial risks.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: AI should and can be made to trust making financial decisions based on human inputs. For example a particular stock selected by AI can be purchased based on the input it is given. When AI are allowed to take decisions based on human input. The human input will be something like : using a particular indicator say EMA9 crosses above EMA15 then it can buy the stock. For any human beings it is difficult to access all the stock where which indicator is being positive, but AI once tunned can do it.

column2: Please explain whether you agree or disagree and why.
column3: Something like this should only be possible if the user has authorised the decisions and the AI chatbot cannot act without the user's permission.
